metadata.name: MSHTA Suspicious Execution 01
metadata.comment: Detection for mshta.exe suspicious execution patterns sometimes involving file polyglotism

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\mshta.exe')) AND (contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('vbscript')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.jpg')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.png')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.lnk')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.xls')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.doc')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.zip')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('.dll'))))

output.summary: Detection for mshta.exe suspicious execution patterns sometimes involving file polyglotism

metadata.objective: False positive: False positives depend on scripts and administrative tools used in the monitored environment References: http://blog.sevagas.com/?Hacking-around-HTA-files, https://0x00sec.org/t/clientside-exploitation-in-2018-how-pentesting-has-changed/7356, https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/dotnet/framework/data/xml/xslt/xslt-stylesheet-scripting-using-msxsl-script, https://medium.com/tsscyber/pentesting-and-hta-bypassing-powershell-constrained-language-mode-53a42856c997, https://twitter.com/mattifestation/status/1326228491302563846
